title: Jehoshaphat's Victory
shortSummary: 2 Chronicles 20 recounts King Jehoshaphat's response to a formidable alliance of enemies threatening Judah. Through fasting, prayer, prophetic encouragement, and worship, God delivers Judah without them needing to fight, demonstrating His sovereign power and faithfulness. The chapter concludes with Jehoshaphat's reign marked by peace and a warning against ungodly alliances.
timeline: c. 870 BC - Reign of Jehoshaphat in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jehoshaphat
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who leads the nation in seeking the Lord through prayer and fasting during a crisis, demonstrating faith and reliance on God.

keyCharacters.name: Jahaziel
keyCharacters.description: A Levite prophet filled with the Spirit of the Lord who encourages Judah with God's message that the battle belongs to Him.

keyCharacters.name: Eliezer
keyCharacters.description: A prophet who later rebukes Jehoshaphat for his alliance with the wicked king Ahaziah, foretelling the failure of their joint maritime venture.

outline.heading: The Threat and Judah’s Response
outline.description: A coalition of enemies threatens Judah, prompting King Jehoshaphat to fear but seek the Lord through fasting and gathering the people to pray.

outline.heading: Jehoshaphat’s Prayer and Remembrance of God’s Faithfulness
outline.description: Jehoshaphat appeals to God’s sovereignty, recalling His past deliverance and covenant promises, expressing Judah’s dependence on Him.

outline.heading: Prophetic Assurance and Divine Strategy
outline.description: The Spirit of the Lord comes upon Jahaziel, who delivers God’s message that the battle belongs to Him and instructs Judah not to fight but to trust.

outline.heading: Praise, Worship, and God’s Deliverance
outline.description: Jehoshaphat leads worship and appoints singers; as they praise, God sets an ambush causing the enemy armies to destroy each other, securing a miraculous victory.

outline.heading: Thanksgiving and Aftermath
outline.description: Judah gathers abundant spoil, blesses God in the Valley of Berachah, returns to Jerusalem with joy, and experiences peace as God grants rest from enemies.

outline.heading: Jehoshaphat’s Later Reign and Warning
outline.description: Jehoshaphat continues to reign righteously but makes a misguided alliance with wicked Ahaziah, resulting in prophetic rebuke and failure of their maritime plans.

application: In times of fear and uncertainty, seek God first through prayer and fasting, trusting His sovereignty over all situations.
Listen attentively to God’s prophetic word and be encouraged that the battle belongs to Him, not to us.
Incorporate worship and praise as powerful weapons in spiritual battles, acknowledging God’s mercy and faithfulness.
Avoid ungodly alliances that compromise your faith, as they can lead to spiritual and practical failure.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Hearken ye, all Judah, and ye inhabitants of Jerusalem, and thou king Jehoshaphat, Thus saith the LORD unto you, Be not afraid nor dismayed by reason of this great multitude; for the battle is not yours, but God's.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s sovereign control and reassures believers that victory comes from Him, not by human strength.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall not need to fight in this battle: set yourselves, stand ye still, and see the salvation of the LORD with you, O Judah and Jerusalem: fear not, nor be dismayed; to morrow go out against them: for the LORD will be with you.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches the importance of faith and obedience, trusting God’s deliverance even when circumstances seem dire.

keyVerses.text: And when he had consulted with the people, he appointed singers unto the LORD, and that should praise the beauty of holiness, as they went out before the army, and to say, Praise the LORD; for his mercy endureth for ever.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the power of worship and praise as a declaration of God’s enduring mercy and presence in the midst of battle.

keyVerses.text: So the realm of Jehoshaphat was quiet: for his God gave him rest round about.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes that true peace and rest come from God’s protection and blessing over His people.
